- So I wanna talk about two different groups of people.
We here are vibing on Ethereum, right?
We all go to the raves,
or we try to go to the raves and make it in one piece.
We like hack in the basement,
like proud to be here in this conference,
and among friends, again,
it feels very nice to be here surrounded by people.
We love people that are vibing with us.
There's another set of people that we discuss much less,
which is people that are living on Ethereum, right?
People who actually use Ethereum as a tool
for their everyday life.
And of course there's an overlap between the two, right?
Like some people here probably get paid in crypto
or in Ethereum or Ethereum stablecoins.
Some people might spend some of that every month.
And yeah, that's one of the things that I wanted to
bring your attention to,
the fact that there's two groups.
There's an intersection in the middle,
but in general, I think we, or myself,
given that I've dedicated my time to explore this space
because I care about financial inclusion
and I care about the good potential for this technology,
even myself, I feel like I haven't dedicated enough time
to talk about the other group.
So I'm gonna talk a little bit about what I've learned.
But first, like recognizing that,
which group would I be a part of?
Do I live in Ethereum or not?
This was in 2018, two good friends,
and I hacked on ETH monocidus.
That was my first Ethereum event ever.
And again, the vibe was great.
This is where I got to meet the community.
And we hacked on a project that was like non-financial,
nothing related to using Ethereum as money
or stablecoins weren't even a thing back then.
And it was great community.
It was a good experience.
And then coming from Venezuela,
like experienced high inflation.
So this is like, gives me another reason
to vibe with the community.
The values of having better money,
giving people access to better money and all that.
But the fact is, I went to school in the United States,
I have a bank account in the US.
And I'm part of that,
like group of financially privileged people
that many of us also are, right?
I care about FDIC insurance,
I care about having stable savings in dollars.
And I know that we are building services now
that are approaching those levels,
or maybe even will beat those levels of resilience and trust.
But we're not quite there yet.
So, I mean, I use credit cards
and I enjoy their convenience.
So if I were to be completely honest,
I'm part of this first group of like,
more vibing on Ethereum than living on Ethereum.
So I've tried to get closer to the other group
by asking questions, by seeking them out,
especially people who were maybe not so much
in the intersection, because I'm sure here in this conference,
we can find people in the intersection.
But people who maybe dislike Ethereum,
or maybe not even think about Ethereum much,
people who wouldn't come to a conference
because, or to a Devgen conference,
because Ethereum doesn't mean as much to them,
because they have other parts of their life
that they value better.
And there's nothing wrong with that.
Started working at Bit Refill.
It's a company that's been around since 2015.
It's focused on Bitcoin in the beginning,
but now there's other coins and tokens that we accept.
And it's very convenient, for example, to refill a phone.
So if you've got your cloud of sim cards
that you got on this conference,
you can go online and top them up.
And it's a lot of countries.
And this gives me the opportunity
to talk to people who are not necessarily using Ethereum
or services on Ethereum,
because they vibe with the community.
They're not part of the community,
but because it gives them a superpower
that they didn't have before,
which is it could be filling up a phone,
could be other services that we offer as well,
like buying gift cards.
So you can offload your crypto that you have
without necessarily going through a bank account and so on.
So while it's nice to talk to the people in this conference
and you feel like in your comfort zone,
I think, yeah, like I've started to talk more
to customers to be refilled in particular here.
And I can't say that I've learned that much yet from them,
but I have, like sparked my curiosity,
and I think I have more questions than answering this talk,
but I hope that you can also get questions
from my explorations so far.
So I've got two archetypes here that I wanna discuss.
So the first one is George, he lives in the USA,
he worked in oil and gas,
and what he wants is to make money fast.
And there may be some people here
that also conceive Ethereum as an investment tool
and as a way to invest smartly in protocols
that will change the world
and that you'll get rewarded for it.
Nothing wrong with that.
George in particular, remember,
he doesn't care much about Ethereum,
he wants to make money fast,
it's like, who wouldn't like that, right?
And he can use any means that he deems
moral, legal, convenient to attain that goal.
So in 2019, maybe he was working as an Amazon reseller.
So he used websites like these
to like engaging activities like drop shipping
or just like flipping products,
identifying products that would sell for a premium
because he thought this would be a good way
to make money fast.
Fast forward to 2020, then he discovered Etoro, right?
And you may be familiar with it,
and then he started trading Forex, right?
And he wasn't particularly interested
in the financial world in the beginning,
but he saw this as a way to make money fast.
And you know, it's evolved into this
as like a side job, right?
Then in 2021, he discovered Uniswap.
And suddenly he became an Ethereum user,
but not necessarily an Ethereum community member, right?
'Cause remember, this guy doesn't really care
much about Ethereum, he cares about making money fast.

you know, the vault, the investment, the staking,
all those new verbs that will be invented soon,
it's so much, you know, like there's so many options here.
So you could say that Binance kind of superseded Ethereum
for this guy as the way to fulfill his goal,
which is making money fast.
Let's go to another case.
Silvia is a copywriter from Argentina,
and she wants access to a US dollar account
because she doesn't trust her national currency much.

from Cuba, from Venezuela, from other places

And I think we would all agree that the community values
are that there's nothing wrong with wanting
to have more financial stability in your life.
So remember, she doesn't really care much about Ethereum,
she's not part of the community,
she doesn't vibe with us, you wouldn't go to the race,

fees were pretty low, a 10 cents of a dollar.

maybe it's Metamask and she got paid using tether,
and then she used telegram groups to offload that
into her Argentine bank account,
just tried to preserve the value of the dollar
as much as possible before actually cashing it out
to the bank, right?
And now there's better options for this,
but in 2020, suddenly the fees were $15, right?
And I remember it says, and then what did Sylvia do?
She just switched to Tron, because again,
tether has been a tool that has been around for a while,
you may have your opinions about it,
and we as technologists may have some concerns
or some fears about it, and certainly the same with Tron,
but guess what, it's a tool.
She doesn't really care much about the technology,
she doesn't care about the community,
she cares about not spending $15 on every transaction
that she makes, so of course, she switched there.
Then 2021, maybe the fee went up a little bit,
but she's still happy with Tron,
and then again, in 2022, she switched to using Binance,
because Binance pays now ubiquitous,
she can pay for anything, and if she ignores
the casino part of Binance that doesn't really interest her,
Binance is her crypto bank, and nowadays,
there are people building crypto banks
that have maybe more aligned goals with us than Binance,
where maybe it's not so driven towards participating
in money-making activities, just like the first guy, George,
but just to preserve the value, more
like your typical bank account experience.
So, and then it's also convenient because she doesn't,
no longer has to use her telegram groups,
she can just go on a peer-to-peer marketplace about Binance,
and she can find enough really fast,
and it's also like, it's very cheap,
the fees for this service are cheap,
and to receive or send UCT within Binance users is free,
so again, convenience wins in this case.
So, after that, in 2022, what may happen?
Maybe she will convert from Tether to BUSC,
it's because maybe Binance will provide further incentives
to use BUSC.
So, what about, why doesn't she use,
as technologies and as part of the community,
we may ask ourselves, why doesn't Sylvia use optimism,
arbitrum, like Ziggy's think, why isn't she on die?
Like, we would like her to be on,
like part of better aligned, more credibly neutral systems,
and the systems that have her well-being more

or, you know, there's many risks with other,
like with using other tools that have not been built

or some of the tools of Ethereum at least have been built.
So, we would like to kind of push these tools to her,
but we haven't done a great job at marketing them,
we haven't done a great job at making them accessible
in the markets where they are needed most, right?
So, she'll probably gravitate towards Binance, right?
So, I think this is, just, again,
like strikes a question that I've had for many years,
and I think I still haven't resulted yet.
So, who is Ethereum for?
And who, like whom should we prioritize,
and how should we measure our success?
Is TVL, for example, a good way to measure Ethereum's success?
Or is adoption, a peer to peer markets,
a better way to do that?
So, maybe, I wanna open it up.
I know, like, this stock is short on purpose

on your experience and maybe compliment the two examples
that we just showed here.
If anyone here gets paid in crypto
and is comfortable like sharing an experience,
and I can, I'm happy to go first,
I've been paid in USCC sometimes,
and my experience has been that,

I can cash out USCC one to one for US dollars in a bank account,

Even though, you know, it's huge inflation, whatever,
it's still a means for me to preserve my savings
that's way better than, for example,
keeping the money in Colombian pesos

and the number of people here is obviously, right?
So, I use that tool to be able to cash out

So, maybe that's something that is, again,

but maybe someone like Sylvia

- Yeah, I think, like, our goal here should be
